reviews.text: I had very high expectations for Hotel Zum Turken, as it is the highest rated place in Berchtesgaden on TripAdvisor. Unfortunately, I was disappointed with what we received and I feel it important to write my own review and tell my story, as I went on the other 17 stellar reviews of this place in booking it.
reviews.title: Disappointed

reviews.text: First of all, do not plan to stay at Hotel Zum Turken unless you have a car. My wife and I used the train to Berchtesgaden, as we are backpackers. There are town buses that run from the Berchtesgaden bus station to the hotel; however, they are only hourly, the last one leaves the town at 6:15pm (pretty early), the fare is quite hefty (almost 3 Euro pp one way for a 9 minute ride!) and there is still a 10-minute steep walk back down the road to the driveway and another 5-minute steep walk back up the driveway to the hotel. If backpacking, don’t plan to have any nightlife in Berchtesgaden and have an early dinner to make the last 6:15pm bus. Oh, and even if you make the 6:15pm bus, Frau Scharfenburg will ask you to let her know if you plan to arrive after 6pm.
reviews.title: OutStanding!
One of the best lodging experiences we've ever had!
reviews.text: The hotel setting is magnificent, set at 3,000 feet in the Alps with great mountain views. Outside was typical cute Bavarian style. When we saw the main floor, it was smoky from the hotel bar off to the left and seemed very outdated. Perhaps someone older may disagree with my assessment, but the best way I can explain it is that the hotel appears not to have changed since perhaps the 60’s, and if the owners were trying to retain the original feel of the place from an era gone by, some of the décor works but some certainly needs upgrading.

reviews.title: Absolutely the Most Wonderful Place to Stay
reviews.text: When making the reservation for the room, there were two options: 62 Euro for shared bath or 92 Euro for private. My wife and I felt that shared bath was OK, and given all the great reviews on TripAdvisor, we went for the 62 Euro room. I cannot comment on what you get for the 92 Euro price, and based on the other reviews, my guess is that they are much better rooms that have balconies and views of the Alps in the front of the hotel, as well as having a private bath. If I had known the differences between 62 and 92 Euro, I would have gone for the 92 Euro rooms. Our room was a major let down. It was #20. Our room faced the parking lot behind the hotel, although we did have a view of Hitler’s Eagles Nest if we angled ourselves properly to look out the small window. Walls were totally stark white with one needlepoint picture for décor. Although it was a “double room,” the beds were aligned one in front of another rather than next to one another, and the room was not even wide enough to put our beds together, so my wife and I slept apart. I think my biggest frustration was having to be in the room early, and knowing there are magnificent views from other rooms in the hotel that I wasn’t getting. Additionally, based on the number of cars in the parking lot, people at breakfast in the morning, and people walking around the hotel, it was not full. Therefore, my other disappointment was that we were given a room facing the parking lot rather than the front of the hotel, even if all 62 Euro rooms were the same and lacked a balcony.

reviews.title: Unbelivable
reviews.text: There were pluses that others have written about and I would echo. The shared bath on our floor was a retreat, as it had a massive, new soak-in tub and very roomy shower. It was adorned in pink, smelled very nice, and was the highlight of the floor. Beds were comfy with nice linens and the in-room sinks were also new. The breakfast in the morning was tremendous, with lots of very good food. Everyone was very friendly in the morning to both my wife and I. There are lots of interesting plaques, certificates, and pictures on the walls. The reason why everyone is drawn to Zum Turken is the history. The hotel was used by the Nazi’s as a Gestapo headquarters and the hotel is right next to a former Hitler residence. You can also tour the bunkers right below the hotel, which is certainly a highlight. The Dokumentation Oversalzburg museum is up the hill and within walking distance.

reviews.title: A Treasure!
reviews.text: Given its location near the former Berghof on "Hitler's mountain" this hotel will be forever connected with Third Reich history. The views are spectacular, the rates are reasonable, the breakfast is great, the people you meet will likely share an interest in WWII, and the innkeeper, Frau Scharfenberg, is a wonderful woman who will make you feel right at home. If I were in the area again this would be the only venue that I would pursue.

reviews.title: Loved this hotel twice
reviews.text: I went to this hotel twice and enjoyed both times my stay there!
You get what you have expected and I personally loved the old fashioned hotel run by Mrs. Ingrid Scharfenberg.
reviews.title: Great for history buffs
Don't think twice about it!
reviews.text: Some of the rooms have splendid views
People, who have an interest in history, should go there for a few nights and visit from there the Eagles Nest as well.

reviews.title: Great hotel

reviews.text: I stayed at this hotel July ’06, and I have mixed feeling about the hotel because of the issues involved. The hotel is closely tied to 20th century German history. The underground bunker tunnels, which are open 6 AM to 6 PM are worth a visit (exact coin change is needed before 9 AM to open the turnstile). The current owner, Frau Scharfenberg is definitely the sweetest and kindest hotelier around. She makes up for a lot of the substantial shortcomings which will be listed below.
reviews.title: Interesting hotel, mixed feelings

likes.liked: — Most gracious hostess/owner, ample parking, hotel facade
likes.disliked: — no elevator, no tv, poor bathroom facilities, disappointing interior

reviews.text: On the positive side …. the buffet breakfast, while not being necessarily excellent, is definitely above the class of the hotel itself. Hotel has ample parking in its yard (actually one can probably turn an 18 wheeler in the big yard). Frau Scharfenberg is fluent in English, and one of the kindest ladies around. The room I stayed in had a nice view of the mountain, but that is sort of average for this geographic area of the world. The street level bar is very nice and well stocked. It is based on the honor system, and one notes down one’s consumption to be added to the bill at the end. Two beers and a hard liquor ran me under 9 Euros, quite reasonable. The bar/sitting area has a TV, the only TV in the hotel.
reviews.title: Living history

reviews.text: On the other hand ….. hotel has a number of problems, or lack of features if you will. The hotel façade is quite attractive, but the interior is quite plain. The corridors are long, white, dark and plain, resembling a dormitory. The room door are quite plain. Most of the building charm lies in its façade rather than the interior. When one comes in, one gets a key to the hotel door itself. It turns out that many tourists seeing the façade, are looking to come inside and check the interior ……. thing that Frau Scharfenberg just can’t manage any longer at her age. The reception, and front door, are locked at 6 PM, so one better check in before 6 PM. The lady does tell one to call if one is going to check in after 6 PM, but she fails to advise prospective clients that the call is mandatory if one wishes to check in. Building has neither a people elevator nor a luggage elevator. The bar TV is the only TV in the hotel. When one enters the one’s room, there is a small hallway. The toilet is on the right, the tub/shower on the left, and the sink is in the room. The toilet and tub/shower have drapes separating them from the hallway. These days, these facilities are generally separated by doors, and all 3 are in a single room, not spread about the room/entrance hallway.
reviews.title: Great Place for History Buffs

reviews.text: Unfortunately, the lady’s husband passed away last year. He used to be the one responsible for the restaurant. Since then, there is no longer a lunch/dinner restaurant, short of the above average breakfast. Lady is not able to find the help she needs to run the restaurant. The Intercontinental,. “the conti”, is a steep 10 mins. climb up the hill, and some other rustic stuben is a 15 mins drive down the road. The conti has a French restaurant, and an international restaurant with terrace and nice salad buffet, (it has more than just lettuce, including seafood stuff). The conti casual restaurant was closed when I dropped by on Saturday evening. BTW, Salzburg is only a 15 miles drive over, maybe a 15 minutes drive down the main drag, once one gets to it. I did not prep Salzburg as a tourist attraction for this trip, but I drove there once for dinner, while looking to feel the gas tank. Once there, look for the “Zentrum”, which is on the river bank, and there is a tunnel that will lead you in.
reviews.title: Excellent Hotel

reviews.text: The hotel is very reasonably priced. It has the feel of a 2 star hotel, based on a 5 star system. The hotel façade, history, and host gracious hospitality are by far the place best assets, even if they don’t quite make up for the other serious deficiencies.
reviews.title: Wonderful stay.
